Booth]] | HCYear = 3rd | OffCoach = | OCYear = | DefCoach = | DCYear = | OScheme = | DScheme = | StadiumArena = Antelope Field | Champion = | BowlTourney = | BowlTourneyResult = | ConfChamp = | ConfChampResult = }} The '''1902 Nebraska Cornhuskers football team''' was the representative of the [[University of Nebraska-Lincoln|University of Nebraska]] in the [[1902 college football season]]. The team was coached by [[Walter C. Booth|Walter C. "Bummy" Booth]] and played their home games at Antelope Field in [[Lincoln, Nebraska]]. ==Before the season== Coach Booth entered his third season hoping to improve upon the 6-2 record of the previous year. The roster shrunk somewhat over previous years and was now down to just 19 players. ==Schedule== {{Cite web|url=http://www.huskers.com/SportSelect.dbml?SPSID=3&SPID=22&DB_OEM_ID=100&KEY=&Q_SEASON=1902 |title =Football - 1902 Schedule/Results |accessdate=2009-11-13|publisher=University of Nebraska-Lincoln Athletics Department}} {| class="wikitable" |- ! '''Lincoln High at Nebraska'''
12Total
[[Lincoln High School (Lincoln, Nebraska)|Lincoln High]] 0
'''â¢ Nebraska''' 27
* '''Date:''' 1902-09-20 * '''Location:''' Antelope Field â¢ [[Lincoln, Nebraska]]
The Lincoln high schoolers continued their exercise in futility in hoping to knock off the university squad in the annual preseason exhibition game, losing for the 5th time in five games. {{Cite web|url=http://www.huskermax.com/1900s.html|title=the 1900s|accessdate=2009-11-13|publisher=HuskerMax}} {{-}} ===Doane===
'''Doane at Nebraska'''
12Total
[[Doane College|Doane]] 000
'''â¢ Nebraska''' 222951
* '''Date:''' 1902-09-27 * '''Location:''' Antelope Field â¢ Lincoln, Nebraska
Doane's latest attempt to best the Cornhuskers fell completely apart as Nebraska scored seemingly at will against the overpowered Doane squad, and extended their series lead to 8-2. {{Cite web|url=http://www.huskernews.com/vnews/display.v/ART/2006/05/13/4478804c667c3?in_archive=1|title=1902 Game Recaps|accessdate=2009-11-13|publisher=Husker Press Box}} {{-}} ===Colorado===
'''Nebraska at Colorado'''
12Total
'''â¢ Nebraska''' 5510
[[Colorado Buffaloes football|Colorado]] 000
* '''Date:''' 1902-10-04 * '''Location:''' [[Boulder, Colorado]]
{{see also|Colorado-Nebraska rivalry}}Nebraska traveled again to Boulder, to meet Colorado for the second time. One Cornhusker score in each half, combined with a stiff defensive effort to secure Nebraska's third straight shutout, secured the victory and put Nebraska out to a 2-0 series lead. {{-}} ===Grinnell===
'''Grinnell at Nebraska'''
12Total
[[Grinnell College|Grinnell]] 000
'''â¢ Nebraska''' 12517
* '''Date:''' 1902-10-11 * '''Location:''' Antelope Field â¢ Lincoln, Nebraska * '''Game weather:''' Rain
Nebraska's star halfback was out with an injury, but neither the loss of his efforts nor the driving rain prevented the Cornhuskers from posting yet another shutout victory, allowing Nebraska to take over the series lead 3-2. {{-}} ===Minnesota===
'''Minnesota at Nebraska'''
12Total
[[1902 Minnesota Golden Gophers football team|Minnesota]] 000
'''â¢ Nebraska''' 066
* '''Date:''' 1902-10-18 * '''Location:''' Northrop Field â¢ [[Minneapolis|Minneapolis, Minnesota]]
Nebraska traveled to Minneapolis to face the feared powerhouse Minnesota team for the third time, hoping to finally come away with a win and avenge the two losses recorded against them so far. The hard fought game remained scoreless until the final minutes, when the Cornhuskers managed the only points of the day on a touchdown. This was the first of Minnesota's only two losses of the season, and extremely remarkable considering that Minnesota would finish the 1902 season by outscoring its opponents 335-34, including eight shutout victories. {{-}} ===Missouri===
'''Nebraska vs. Missouri'''
12Total
'''â¢ Nebraska''' 6612
{{cfb link|year=1902|school=University of Missouri|team=Missouri Tigers|title=Missouri}} 000
* '''Date:''' 1902-10-25 * '''Location:''' [[Saint Joseph, Missouri]] * '''Game Attendance:''' 2,000
{{see also|MissouriâNebraska rivalry}}Meeting Missouri on new neutral ground, in St. Joseph for the first time, the Cornhuskers ended an early scoring attempt by Missouri at the Nebraska 7-yard line, and then shut down the Tigers for the rest of the day, while making two touchdowns of their own to extend the shutout streak to 6, and the series lead to 8-3. {{-}} ===Haskell===
'''Haskell at Nebraska'''
12Total
[[Haskell Indian Nations University|Haskell]] 000
'''â¢ Nebraska''' 62228
* '''Date:''' 1902-11-01 * '''Location:''' Antelope Field â¢ Lincoln, Nebraska * '''Game Attendance:''' 6,000
The Haskell Indians never really had a plausible chance to make a game of it, as Nebraska dominated the contest from beginning to end in yet another shutout victory, extending their series over Haskell to 2-0. {{-}} ===Kansas===
'''Kansas at Nebraska'''
12Total
{{cfb link|year=1902|school=University of Kansas|team=Kansas Jayhawks|title=Kansas}} 0
'''â¢ Nebraska''' 16
* '''Date:''' 1902-11-08 * '''Location:''' Antelope Field â¢ Lincoln, Nebraska
One of Nebraska's touchdown came on a trick placekick that was instead run in for a touchdown. Nebraska's shutout streak was now eight games in a row, and the Cornhuskers pulled ahead in the series for the first time, 6-5. {{-}} ===Knox===
'''Knox at Nebraska'''
12Total
[[Knox College (Illinois)|Knox]] 000
'''â¢ Nebraska''' 707
* '''Date:''' 1902-11-15 * '''Location:''' Antelope Field â¢ Lincoln, Nebraska
Nebraska hosted Knox for the first game between the teams, and the highlight of the event was the defensive efforts of both teams. Although Knox kept Nebraska to just 7 points in the first half before closing them down, the Cornhuskers once again prevented the opponent from scoring at all. Knox came close, however, before turning over the ball on downs just inches from the end zone. {{-}} ===Northwestern===
'''Northwestern at Nebraska'''
12Total
{{cfb link|year=1902|school=Northwestern University|team=Northwestern Purple|title=Northwestern}} 0
'''â¢ Nebraska''' 12
* '''Date:''' 1902-11-27 * '''Location:''' Antelope Field â¢ Lincoln, Nebraska
Nebraska met Northwestern for the first time, hosting another Illinois team in Lincoln for the second week in a row. The penalty-ridden game was an emotional battle, with Northwestern reporting rough treatment on the field by the Cornhuskers. Despite seven holding penalties against Nebraska, each of which required turning over the ball according to the rules of the time, the Cornhuskers still held Northwestern scoreless for its tenth straight shutout win to close out the season with a perfect record. {{-}} ==After the season== Nebraska wrapped up coach Booth's third season with an unprecedented full slate of shutout victories, including the exhibition game at the beginning of the season, scoring 186 points while keeping all opponents off the scoreboard. Nebraska's hopes to be considered the Western Champion were dashed when Michigan was instead selected, following their 23-6 win over Minnesota, which was Minnesota's only season defeat except for their earlier loss to Nebraska. Being an independent seemed to work against Nebraska's title consideration, as the other contenders were members of the [[Big Ten Conference|Big Nine Conference]]. Nebraska applied to the Big Nine following the season, but the application was denied. Coach Booth's record at Nebraska improved to 21-3-1 (.860), and the program's overall record improved to 62-28-5 (.679). ==References== {{Reflist}} {{NebraskaCornhuskersFootballNavbox}} {{DEFAULTSORT:1902 Nebraska Cornhuskers Football Team}} [[Category:1902 college football season|Nebraska]] [[Category:Nebraska Cornhuskers football seasons]] [[Category:College football undefeated seasons]]
